<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the apparatus she uses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 125, 769, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 381, 336, 400]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[591, 381, 663, 400]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 144, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 413, 918, 447]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly, with the help of a diagram, how you would use a metre rule and set square to measure the length \(d\) of a pendulum as accurately as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 459, 235, 477]]<|/det|>
Diagram:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 630, 917, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 146, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 918, 694]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the pendulum so that \(d = 50.0 \text{cm}\). She displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 601, 709]]<|/det|>
She measures the time \(t_1\) for 20 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 721, 180, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 721, 495, 740]]<|/det|>
Record the time \(t_1\) shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 752, 584, 885]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 897, 532, 916]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 928, 920, 947]]<|/det|>
<form>t_1 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T_{1}\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 178, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<form>T_1 = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 144, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 702, 229]]<|/det|>
The student adjusts the pendulum until the distance \(d\) is \(100.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 873, 260]]<|/det|>
She repeats the procedure and records the time \(t_2\) for 20 oscillations and the period \(T_2\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 280, 917, 304]]<|/det|>
\[t_2 = \frac{39.80\mathrm{s}}{19.99\mathrm{s}}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 345, 917, 368]]<|/det|>
\[T_2 = \frac{1.99\mathrm{s}}{19.99\mathrm{s}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
She measures the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the pendulum bob. The reading on the balance is shown in Fig. 1.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 425, 579, 533]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 548, 534, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 643, 598]]<|/det|>
Record mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the pendulum bob to the nearest gram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 610, 920, 628]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{A}} = .................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 641, 737, 660]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure using a pendulum bob of mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 682, 917, 707]]<|/det|>
<form>m_{\mathrm{B}} = .................................................... 109 \mathrm{g}

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 373, 737]]<|/det|>
She obtains these results:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 745, 917, 765]]<|/det|>
<form>distance $d =$ ....................................... 50.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 777, 917, 798]]<|/det|>
<form>period $T_3 =$ ....................................... 1.39 s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 808, 917, 828]]<|/det|>
<form>distance $d =$ ....................................... 100.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 839, 917, 860]]<|/det|>
<form>period $T_4 =$ ....................................... 2.02 s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Using the results \(T_{1}\) , \(T_{2}\) , \(T_{3}\) and \(T_{4}\), for the period of each of the pendulums, tick \((\checkmark)\) the response that matches your results within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[238, 176, 574, 198]]<|/det|>

the period \(T\) is affected by \(m\) only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 271, 549, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 663, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates some thermal properties of sand and water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 364, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 129, 752, 390]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 403, 534, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 146, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
The thermometer in Fig. 3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{S}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 481, 824, 521]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 540, 534, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 570, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{S}} =\) .................................................... $^\circ \mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 146, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 920, 634]]<|/det|>
The student is supplied with hot water at a temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\). She records the temperature of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 641, 918, 660]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) ..................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 920, 711]]<|/det|>
She pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker that contains sand. Initially, the sand is at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 628, 743]]<|/det|>
She measures the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 750, 918, 770]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) ..................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 181, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 870, 804]]<|/det|>
Calculate the rise in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the sand using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{M}} - \theta_{\mathrm{S}})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[567, 816, 920, 834]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................................. $^\circ \mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 848, 181, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<form>........................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 925, 920, 943]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 897, 91]]<|/det|>
Calculate the fall in temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 134, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\) .................................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
Calculate the ratio \(S\) using the equation \(S = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{R}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{F}}}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 277, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into a clean beaker that contains \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water at room temperature. She records the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 510, 135]]<|/det|>
1. ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 510, 166]]<|/det|>
2. ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 164, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 143, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
The student measures the volume of the dry sand using a measuring cylinder before carrying out the experiment. Tick \((\checkmark)\) the boxes that show the precautions that she should take in order to obtain an accurate reading.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 247, 193, 339]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 256, 598, 275]]<|/det|>
Take the reading at the bottom of the meniscus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 287, 808, 306]]<|/det|>
Tap the measuring cylinder to make sure the top of the sand is horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 319, 663, 337]]<|/det|>
View the scale of the measuring cylinder at right angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the bending of \(1 \text{m}\) length strips of different materials. She compares how far they bend when loaded at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the material from which the strips are made affects the bending of the strips when loaded at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 537, 183]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 633, 214]]<|/det|>
strips of wood, plastic, steel and aluminium, each of length \(1 \text{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 311, 228]]<|/det|>
a set of slotted masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 222, 243]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 606, 260]]<|/det|>
a G-clamp (used to hold the strips to the laboratory bench).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 740, 291]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 324, 322]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 636, 354]]<|/det|>
• draw a diagram to show the arrangement of the apparatus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 507, 431]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
• draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 491, 655, 509]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 42, 512, 58]]<|/det|>
